page.title: 13FOLKLORE AND SUPERSTITION
page.content: {FOLKLORE AND SUPERSTITION} A window in the Abbey reminds all local people of the traditional acclamation -{"Pershore God Help Us" uttered when the local crop yield was poor and{"Pershore Where do you {think?"} when the local yield was high and the market prosperous. Older people tell us that it was {unheard of to put shoes on the table, {to wash clothing on Good Friday and to {wash on New Year's Day -}The shoes on the table superstition is a common one. Washing on Good Friday would result in Christ's blood appearing on the clothing and washing on New Year's Day will "wash out" a member of your family in some tragic way. It was felt that Pershore people were generally no more nor less superstitious than any other part of England.
